final_answer.precision_note: The minimum number of significant figures in the input data (current 1.50 A and time 30.0 min) is three. The final answer is reported to three significant figures.

method: First, calculate the total charge passed (Q) by converting time to seconds: $t = 30.0 \text{ min} \times 60 \text{ s/min} = 1800 \text{ s}$. $Q = I \times t = 1.50 \text{ A} \times 1800 \text{ s} = 2700 \text{ C}$. Next, calculate the moles of electrons ($n_{e^\text{-}}$) using the Faraday constant ($F = 96500 \text{ C mol}^{-1}$): $n_{e^\text{-}} = Q / F = 2700 \text{ C} / 96500 \text{ C mol}^{-1} \approx 0.027979 \text{ mol}$. From the half-equation $\text{Cu}^{2+} + 2e^\text{-} \to \text{Cu}$, the mole ratio is $2e^\text{-} : 1\text{ Cu}$. Moles of $\text{Cu}$ deposited is $n_{Cu} = n_{e^\text{-}} / 2 \approx 0.013989 \text{ mol}$. Finally, calculate the mass of $\text{Cu}$ using its atomic mass ($63.55$): $m_{Cu} = n_{Cu} \times A_r(Cu) \approx 0.013989 \text{ mol} \times 63.55 \text{ g mol}^{-1} \approx 0.889 \text{ g}$ (3 SF).
checks: Time was correctly converted from minutes to seconds.
The 2:1 mole ratio of electrons to copper from the half-equation was correctly applied.
The final units are mass (g) as required.
